awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Impacts of Massive Black Hole Formation and Evolution Pathways on Gravitational Wave Sources
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is part of a collaborative project to understand how massive black holes form and grow in galaxies in the early universe. The team will use computer simulations of the birth and growth of galaxies in the early universe with different black hole formation models. They will then look for differences in the predicted gravitational wave events between models. They will also search through the simulations for expected optical events that would be associated with the growth of black holes and possible gravitational wave events.

This collaborative project will look at three different black hole seeding mechanisms in cosmological simulations with galaxy formation models as in the IllustrisTNG simulations. These will be traced through hydrodynamical cosmological simulations to determine the astrophysical information that can be extracted from gravitational wave detection of merging massive black holes and electromagnetic observations of galaxies at high redshifts. The data from the simulations will be made public.

This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have carried out a multi-scale, multi-faceted study to probe the origins of massive black holes in the early Universe, as well as the role of massive black hole mergers as gravitational wave (GW) sources. In the local Universe, massive black holes are found in the centers of virtually all massive galaxies and are millions to billions of times more massive than the Sun. Various formation pathways for the “seeds” of these massive black holes have been proposed, but observational evidence has been elusive, and modeling their formation and early growth is computationally challenging.  

GW signals from merging massive black holes provide crucial insights into their evolution. In 2023, the North American Nanohertz Observatory for Gravitational Waves (NANOGrav) and other pulsar timing array collaborations presented strong evidence for a stochastic background of GWs consistent with a cosmological population of inspiraling massive black hole binaries. The upcoming Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA), will detect GWs from massive black hole mergers across vast cosmic distances, making it a promising probe of black hole origins. In addition, the exquisite sensitivity and resolution of the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), which began operations during our project period, has already revolutionized our view of early galaxies and black holes, further motivating our study.

We developed novel methods to model the formation, growth, and mergers of massive black holes using state-of-the-art cosmological simulations. We first used existing IllustrisTNG data to develop a flexible semi-analytic model to calculate in post-processing the black hole formation and merger rates for a range of seeding criteria in low-mass, high-redshift galaxies. This approach improves upon the predictive power of the simple IllustrisTNG seeding prescription and is readily adaptable to other cosmological simulations. In parallel, we implemented a gas-based seeding method in high-resolution cosmological simulations using the AREPO hydrodynamics code. We find that black hole growth is strongly merger-dominated at early times, with minimal contribution from gas accretion. Different black hole seeding mechanisms leave distinct imprints on high-redshift black hole merger rate detectable with LISA.

We then leveraged these results to create a novel sub-grid model for seeding black holes in lower-resolution simulations. Within the high-resolution simulations, the descendants of black hole seeds are used to calibrate a new stochastic seeding model for lower-resolution versions of the initial simulations. This model, based on only galaxy mass, redshift, and an environmental criterion, successfully reproduced the results of detailed gas-based seeding models, including host galaxy properties.

Using our novel seeding models, we created the BRAHMA cosmological simulation suite to predict the high-redshift black hole populations under a range of seeding conditions. Our simulation results are consistent with JWST discoveries of overmassive black holes in high-redshift galaxies, though our most restrictive seeding criteria failed to replicate observations, pointing towards more efficient seeding or accretion mechanisms. The BRAHMA simulations also show that seeding signatures persist in local black holes hosted in dwarf galaxies, suggesting that such galaxies can serve as probes of black hole origins.

We also investigated the impact of black hole binary inspiral timescales and spin evolution on the GW source population. Using Illustris simulation data, we developed a post-processing model to couple black hole binary spin evolution with inspiral dynamics. This model suggests that a subset of binaries enters the GW phase with misaligned spins, leading to recoil and precession effects that could influence LISA waveforms. We also studied triple black hole systems using the Illustris simulations, finding that a few percent of binary black holes form close triple systems. These systems may undergo strong three-body interactions, enhancing merger rates and contributing to GW signals detectable by pulsar timing arrays and LISA.

As part of the broader impacts of this project, we greatly expanded the scope and activities of the Women in Physics and Astronomy program at the University of Florida (UF). In 2020, this program was integrated into the newly formed Physics Inclusion, Diversity, and Equity Alliance (Phys-IDEA) at UF. We organized events for students to interact with visiting scientists, held seminars and panels about career networking and job searches, provided support to the Gator Chapter of the National Society of Black Physicists, installed LGBTQ-affirming artwork in the physics building, and led faculty DEI trainings. An intergroup dialogue series was also held in the department, focusing on a sense of belonging in physics, and in 2023, we conducted a departmental climate survey. Phys-IDEA was awarded the Excellence in DEI Committee Award by UF's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences in Spring 2023.

Our broader impacts also included an annual series of outreach events in celebration of the UN’s International Day of Women & Girls in Science. We organized keynote public lectures by visiting scientists, a science demo fair for kids held in a local park, events for community members to interact with UF scientists, and multimedia displays around campus.
